name: AI-Native Development Platforms
description: Development tools embedding generative AI directly into the coding process, enabling teams to build software faster through human-AI collaboration. Gartner predicts by 2030, 80% of organizations will evolve large software engineering teams into smaller, AI-augmented teams.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — AI coding assistants (Copilot, Cursor, Claude Code) are rapidly adopted, but full AI-native platforms replacing traditional development are still maturing.

name: AI Supercomputing Platforms
description: Hybrid computing systems combining CPUs, GPUs, AI ASICs, and neuromorphic processors to handle complex workloads at unprecedented speeds. Gartner predicts by 2028, over 40% of leading enterprises will adopt hybrid computing architectures for critical workflows, up from 8% today.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — massive GPU buildouts from hyperscalers and sovereign AI initiatives are accelerating demand for AI supercomputing infrastructure.

name: Confidential Computing
description: Hardware-based security isolating workloads within trusted execution environments to protect sensitive data during processing, preventing even infrastructure providers from accessing information. Gartner predicts by 2029, over 75% of operations on untrusted infrastructure will be secured by confidential computing.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — TEEs are available from major cloud providers, but adoption is still early. Regulatory pressure and AI data privacy concerns are driving interest.

name: Multiagent Systems
description: Networks of specialized AI agents collaborating to achieve shared objectives, enabling adaptive automation across complex business processes through modular, reusable agent solutions.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — agentic AI is the hottest area in tech with major investment from all players, but reliable multi-agent orchestration is still being figured out.

name: Domain-Specific Language Models
description: AI models fine-tuned for particular industries or functions, delivering superior accuracy and compliance compared to general-purpose models. Gartner predicts by 2028, over half of enterprise generative AI models will be domain-specific.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — industry-specific models are emerging in healthcare, legal, and finance, but most enterprises still rely on general-purpose LLMs.

name: Physical AI
description: AI-powered robots, drones, autonomous vehicles, and smart equipment that perceive, decide, and act in physical environments, spanning manufacturing, logistics, and agriculture.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — humanoid robotics attracting massive investment, but practical deployment outside controlled environments remains limited.

name: Preemptive Cybersecurity
description: AI-driven security using predictive analytics to anticipate and prevent threats before they materialize, shifting from reactive to proactive defense. Gartner predicts by 2030, preemptive solutions will account for half of all security spending.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — exposure management and attack surface monitoring are growing fast, but most organizations are still predominantly reactive.

name: Digital Provenance
description: Verification systems ensuring authenticity of software, data, and AI-generated content through tracking origin and integrity. Gartner warns by 2029, enterprises that fail to invest in digital provenance could face sanctions and reputational risks running into billions.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — C2PA and content credentials gaining traction, but ecosystem-wide adoption for combating deepfakes and misinformation is nascent.

name: AI Security Platforms
description: Centralized platforms for monitoring, controlling, and protecting in-house and third-party AI implementations against AI-specific vulnerabilities like prompt injection, data leakage, and model manipulation. Gartner predicts by 2028, over 50% of enterprises will deploy AI security platforms.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — AI security is a fast-growing category as enterprises rush to deploy LLMs, but unified platforms are just emerging.

name: Geopatriation
description: Moving workloads and data from global public clouds to localized or sovereign infrastructure to comply with data residency laws and mitigate geopolitical risks. Gartner predicts by 2030, over 75% of European and Middle Eastern enterprises will geopatriate workloads.
accuracyNote: Too early to score — EU data sovereignty regulations and geopolitical tensions are driving interest, but migration from hyperscaler clouds is slow and costly.
